titlePart.title: The Jamaican Cookery Book
Three Hundred and Sixty-Four Simple Cookery Receipts and Household Hints Collected By Caroline Sullivan

div.p: I do not think I am mistaken in saying that up to the present time a book on native cookery has never been produced in Jamaica: and it is to supply that want that I place before the public the few simple receipts it has been my pleasant occupation to gather together from time to time. I am quite aware that the various methods of cooking here mentioned may be open to criticism. There are doubtless ways known superior to those a knowledge of which I have succeeded in obtaining. But faulty as they may be, I venture to hope that those here given may be of some assistance to new comers, on whose especial behalf this work has been undertaken.

I do not venture to offer any hints to those whose long residence in the island renders them familiar with all the details of our ordinary Jamaica cooking; but from them I should be glad to receive notes on any articles which I may have omitted.

I have carefully refrained from giving European cookery, and have confined myself entirely to the every day dishes which come under immediate notice in this island. Simple as these receipts may be, should any of them prove to be of help and use, I shall feel amply repaid for any trouble I may have taken in collecting them. C.S.

div.head: Preface to the Second Edition
div.p: The kind appreciation with which my Jamaica Cookery Book has been generally received, encourages me to place a second edition of it before the public. Since its publication, I have been fortunate enough to collect between sixty and seventy additional receipts, which may I trust, prove of some small service to those in need of them, as the others have been. Caroline Sullivan
This is prepared in many ways, some preferring it thin, others thick: a good family soup may be made as follows:—

list.item: Two lbs. of Turtle stew meat.
One quart and one pint of water,
One large onion or some skellion
A piece of salt pork and a piece of salt beef
Sauce, lime juice. salt and cayenne pepper.

div.p: Get two lbs. of turtle stew meat or a little less, and stew it down the day before you make your soup, with cloves, cinnamon and mace; next day put the stew and its gravy into a quart and pint of water with half a pound of turtle soup meat; add an onion or some skellion (some people put a turnip and a carrot) some parsley, herbs and tomatoes. When it has boiled half an hour, add the salt pork and salt beef cut in pieces. Let it boil another hour, then remove any fat there may be, which cut in dice, and put it in the tureen with some of the soft gristle as well. Let the soup boil another half hour, adding water if too low; then strain it through a cullender. Put the strained soup back in the pot, and put in a good tablespoonful of flour previously mixed smooth with water and poured in; then add a little Worcester or Harvey's sauce, the juice of a lime, some salt, a little cayenne and stir till it is nice and think like cream. Pour this over the fat and gristle dice in the tureen and serve, adding just before serving a wineglassful of sherry.

div.head: 2. Ochro Soup.

list.item: One and a half pound of salt beef
Seasoning, tomato and skellion and thyme
Penny halfpenny worth of salt pork

div.p: Put the ochros into the water and boil until the seeds get red: then add the pork and beef and go on boiling, adding the seasoning and other ingredients. Chop fine some kale or callilu and add to the soup, and serve. It can be strained if preferred. A few black crabs boiled and added to the soup make it excellent.

div.head: 3. Sugar Bean soup

list.item: Penny halfpenny worth of green fresh sugar beans.
One quart and one pint of water.
Some bones of soup meat and a little salt pork.

div.p: Boil the beans in the water putting it on in cold water. When half done add a little soup meat and some salt pork. If preferred, the beans are left in the soup and it is then served unstrained. Children are especially fond of it, particularly if a little potato or yam be boiled in it also. The addition of a few tomatoes is according to taste.

div.head: Bannabis soup
div.p: This is a large bean, and the soup made from it is particularly delicate.

list.item: Half a cocoanut made into milk.

div.p: A small piece of salt beef and the same of salt pork (or a beef bone or a bit of ham or a tongue bone. Soak the beans for about an hour or more in cold water. Then take them out and strip off the skin and put them into a quart of hot water. Boil half an hour, then add the beef, pork and herbs. Now grate the cocoanut and squeeze out as much milk from it as you can, wringing it through a cloth. This is to be added to the soup just before serving, well stirred in; but the soup itself takes from one hour to one and a half to boil

div.head: 5. Goongoo Peas Soup.

list.item: One half pint of dry goongoos
A penny half penny worth of either salt beef or salt pork.

div.p: Put the peas in cold water (about a quart) and let them boil for two hours and a half with a sprig of thyme and a piece of skellion. thenrub through a cullender smooth and thick, and serve with sippets of dry toast handed. Add the salt pork about half an hour after the peas have been on the fire.

div.head: 6. Red Peas Soup
div.note: N.R.—The natives do not strain their peas soup: they eat the whole thing boiled with yam, coco and dumplings and often with a remarkable concoction called "foo foo" which consists of yam or coco boiled and beaten and then added to the soup. Needless to say, this makes them a decidedly substantial repast. The dumplings are often made with equal parts of flour and cornmeal.
div.p: Put the peas into cold water and boil three hours till the peas are soft, adding penny-half-penny worth of salt pork about two hours and a half after boiling has begun. At the end of three hours time press the peas through a cullender. Serve with dry toast cut in dice.

Needless to say, this makes them a decidedly substantial repast. The dumplings are often made with equal parts of flour and cornmeal.

Put the peas into cold water and boil three hours till the peas are soft, adding penny-half-penny worth of salt pork about two hours and a half after boiling has begun. At the end of three hours time press the peas through a cullender. Serve with dry toast cut in dice.

div.head: 7. White Peas Soup.
div.p: This is prepared in the same way as red peas soup.

div.head: 8. Cockle Cress Soup.
div.p: Put the peas on to boil for two hours and a half putting them on in cold water, with the tomatos (a few) and one large skellion. About one hour afterwards add the salt pork (or beef or ham or tongue bone) and at the end of another hour and a half rub through a callender smooth and thick. Serve, and hand sippets of dry toast to eat with it.

div.head: 9. Coco Soup
div.p: This is a favourite dish amongst the peasantry, especially in the country parts where fresh meat is scarce.

list.item: A penny half penny worth of salt pork and the same of salt beef.
Some dumplings, a little bunch of seasoning and some skellion and tomatos.

div.p: Cut the cocos in halves and put into the water to boil. In about a quarter of an hour, add the pork, beef and seasonings. Boil another quarter of an hour. Then mash up the cocos fine and thick, and serve with some tiny dumplings, any size or shape desired.

div.head: 10. Callilu Soup.
div.p: This is another of the country soups very often used by the people.

list.item: A slice of salt pork and the same of salt beef.

div.p: Trim the callilu by taking off the rough scaly bits from the leaves, and then put it into some boiling water for about a quarter of an hour. Throw away that water and put on a quart of water to boil, meanwhile take the callilu and chop it very fine indeed, then add it to the water: boil a quarter of an hour and then add the beef and pork. In another quarter of an hour it will be fit for table.

div.head: 11. Shrimp Soup.

list.item: One quart and one pint of water.
Pepper and salt, thyme, lime-peel and skellion.
A penny half-penny worth of salt pork or beef.
A little sauce and a squeeze of lime.

div.p: Boil the fish in the quart and pint of water till reduced to a quart. Pick the shrimps and pound the heads, tails and skins fine, then put this and the shrimps into the fish stock, removing the fish. Put in the butter and seasoning and cloves. Boil ten minutes. Take out the shrimps, cut in small pieces and put in the soup tureen. Boil the rest of the ingredients in the stock another half hour. Thicken with a little flour and pour over the shrimps, adding a squeeze of lime.

div.head: 12. Lobster Soup
div.p: Make a little stock first of any kind of fish, till it makes one pint.

list.item: Pepper and salt, parsley, thyme, lime-peel, bread crumbs and onion

div.p: Boil the lobster, seasoning the water it was boiled in; put all the meat of it, except the tail ends and any corals, into a mortar with the shell and pound it all together as fine as possibepossible. Add this to the fish soup stock, and the water the lobster was boiled in; season with pepper and salt, parsley, thyme, lime-peel and some bread crumbs and an onion. Simmer quietly for nearly two hours, then strain it off. Have ready the tail end of the lobsters chopped into dice and the lobster corals which put into the tureen. Add a little milk and a desertspoonful of butter and some nutmeg to the soup and give it one boil; pour into the tureen, and serve: some people like force-meat balls added to this soup.

div.head: 13. Jonga Soup.
div.p: This is prepared similarly to cray fish or bisque soup.
Half a dozen large jongas, butter, seasoning, grated lime-peel, bread crumbs, onion or skellion and milk.

Half fry the jongas in butter, then pound both flesh and shells together (but reserve one or two whole to cut into dice to serve with the soup); pound them in a mortar, season highly, adding some grated lime peel, bread crumbs, onion or skellion with the usual herbs. Boil gently for one hour, strain and put back in the pot for a little with the jongas cut in dice, add a little butter (about a teaspoonful) and half a cupful of milk. Stir well and serve hot.

div.head: 14. Ackee Soup
div.p: Take 12 ackees: pick them well taking out the pink part. Put them into a piece of muslin, and boil them. Put on one quart of water, one pound of beef, a small piece of salt pork or salt beef to make it tasty: also some seasoning, thyme and skellion. Mash the ackees quite smooth and mix them with the soup and boil them all together.

div.head: 15. Cocoanut Soup

list.item: One lb. of beef. One quart of water.
One small piece of salt pork or beef.
Half a pint of hot water.

div.p: Put on one lb. of beef with a piece of salt beef or salt pork, two small white cocos and some skellion and thyme, in one quart of water to boil. Boil it down to one pint. Grate a small cocoanut, throw half a pink of hot water on it, then squeeze out the milk. Pour this milk into the soup and boil up, once. Before putting the cocoanut milk into the soup, the soup must be quite boiled and strained, then add the milk to the boiling soup. Stir well, and serve at once.

div.head: 16. Pepper Pot

list.item: Three tablespoonfuls of pure casseripe to every quart of water, cold. Salt to taste.

div.p: Get an earthen vessel. To every quart of cold water, add three tablespoonfuls of the pure caseripe with salt to taste and a handful of bird peppers. If these cannot be had, use some cayene. Cut the meat into small pieces after being well cooked, and put into the pot; boil well for half an hour. Any sort of meat may be used, all mixed in it, and hard boiled eggs are an improvement. It should be warmed every day, and something added each day.

div.head: 17. Pumpkin Soup

list.item: One large slice of pumkin or half a small pumkin.
One quart and a pint of water.
Either some soup meat or a little salt pork or salt beef.

div.p: Cut up the pumkin and add to the water (either cold or hot), putting with it the soup meat if fresh meat and a little thyme and black pepper; in about half an hour's time add if liked a small bit of salt pork or salt beef, or else salt to taste. In about another half hour strain the soup through a cullender and serve curried: this soup is particularly palatable.

div.head: II. FISH
div.p: Snappers, mullet, king-fish, mackerel, old wife, calepeaver, cutlass, mountain mullet, lobsters, crayfish, oysters, jongas, crabs shrimps and turtle all have their season in Jamaica.
There are two sorts of crabs the white and the black. The former are not generally eaten being foul feeders, but the black crabs are highly esteemed and are counted among the delicacies of Jamaica.

div.head: 18. King-Fish
div.p: This is a much esteemed fish, and is good cooked in any way. Boiled and served with butter and parsley or oyster or anchovy sauce, it must be appreciated by everyone. King-fish steaks, that is king-fish cut up in thick slices and broiled with onions, are excellent, especially if a rich brown gravy be added. Opened and stuffed with bread-crumbs and oysters and served with tomato sauce they make a rich and agreeable dish.

div.head: 19. Mountain Mullet
div.p: These are esteemed ome of Jamaica's delicacies. They are of excellent flavour, but the drawback to them in many people's opinion is the number of small bones they possess. The nicest way of cooking them is rolling them in buttered paper and frying them, sending them to table in the paper: but they can of course be fried plain or boiled if preferred.

div.head: 20. Cutlass
div.p: This is a long ribbony fish and it has small bones at the side, which must be carefully taken away: very good cutlets can be made of this fish, but they make excellent fish cakes or fish pies. They do well for Kedgeree, a mixture of boiled rice, picked fish, mustard, butter and curry powder.

div.head: 21. Calepeaver
div.p: This fish is sometimes called the Salmom of Jamaica. It is a very rich delicately flavoured fish: it is more often to be had in the vicinity of Spanish Town. The size varies, but they are sometimes very fine and large. The best way of cooking this fish is to boil it; putting it on (after carefully cleansing it and rubbing it with lime-juice) in hot water with a little salt in it, boiling slowly; allowing ten minutes boiling to each pound of fish. Shrimp and butter sauce or oyster sauce are good additions, but perhaps butter and parsley is best, and a cut lime handed to squeeze over.

div.head: 22. Jongas
div.p: Jongas, are a kind of small cray-fish which are often found in the mountain rivers. They are cooked like lobsters, and make an excellent stew or fricassee or curry.

div.head: 23. Oysters
div.p: Of these there are two sorts, the round or raw-eaten oyster, and the flat or cooking oyster. The former are small but very delicate in flavour; they can of course also be cooked. The flat oyster is the best for scallops or patties, or in any cooked form. The way to open these is by placing them near the fire when the shells open of themselves.

div.head: 24. Roasted Lobster
div.p: More than half boil it. Then take it out of the water and shell it as quickly as possible. While hot, rub it well with butter, put it in a Dutch oven, baste it well until nicely frothed, and serve with melted butter.

div.head: 25. Lobster Croquettes

list.item: Seasoning, tomato, and pepper, spices, one onion, lime-juice, lime-peel, salt, butter, milk, grated bread, two eggs.

div.p: Shell a small lobster and chop it fine with seasoning and nutmeg, onion, tomato, pepper and thyme, with a little grated lime-peel and some of the juice of the lime and some salt. Add a dessert spoonful of butter and about as much cream or milk and two table-spoonfuls of breaded bread. Mix all together with two beaten eggs: make balls, roll in egg and bread crumb, and fry. Put either a rich white sauce or brown gravy in the dish, the croquettes on the top, and serve very hot.

div.head: 26. Baked Lobster

list.item: Worcester sauce. Jamaica pepper, vinegar, bread crumbs.

div.p: Boil the lobster, then shell and pick it and chop it fine. Add a tablespoonful of butter, plenty of pepper and salt, a little Worcester sauce and some Jamaica pepper just to flavour or some pepper-wine, a little vinegar too. Mix all well together; put it in a small buttered pie-dish, bread-crumb it, put a little dab or so of butter here and there, and bake.

div.head: 27. Lobster Cutlets

list.item: Water, milk, salt, pepper, cayenne, parsley, yolks of two eggs.

div.p: Cut up the lobster, letting the flesh (in dice) weigh 1 lb. Put in a saucepan two oz of butter, two teaspoonfuls of chopped onions; add the lobster and fry for a minute or two. Add one teaspoonful of flour mixed smooth with water, stir in: add half a pint of milk, salt, pepper, and cayenne, two teaspoons of chopped parsley. Let it boil a little, stirring all the time; add the lobster, give it a boil, add the two yolks of eggs: mix quickly and put in a dish to cool. When cool and firm divide into six parts and shape like cutlets; egg and bread crumb twice. Put a piece of the very small claw to the end of each cutlet so as to form a bone. Fry for a few minutes as you would a sole, in plenty of lard or fat; lay on a cloth, and serve on a napkin with a plenty of parsley. No sauce is needed. The lobster may be prepared shaped and bread crumbed some hours before wanted.

div.head: 28. Old Wife
div.p: These are queer flat fish. They should be cooked like the English sole. Wash them carefully and dry them well, then dust over a little flour; egg and bread-crumb them, and fry a light brown, turning them when one side is done. Serve with metled butter and garnish with parsley.

div.head: 29. June Fish
div.p: A cottony fish. It should be stewed in a rich brown sauce with onions, tomatoes, and herbs, and a wineglass of port wine added towards the end of the cooking and thickening with a little flour. A little fresh pepper makes an agreeable addition, but very little.

div.head: 30. Baked Fish No. 1
div.p: Clean, rinse, and wipe dry any kind of fish; rub with salt and pepper; fill with stuffing, the same as for poultry only drier. Sew up and put in a pan with some hot dripping and a lump of butter. Dredge with flour, and lay over the fish a few thin slices of salt pork or bits of butter. Bake one hour and a half, basting occasionally.

div.head: 31. Baked Fish No. 2
div.p: Any cold fish, maccaroni, milk, butter, grated cheese, bread-crumbs and cayenne.
Boil some maccaroni very tender in milk, about twice as much maccaroni as there is cold fish, which should be broken in small pieces and the bones removed.

Mix with it the maccaroni cut in dice, the grated cheese and cayenne. Put it in a flat dish with bread crumbs and some pieces of butter on the top and bake a light brown. Any fish will do for this dish.

div.head: 32. Turtle Cutlets

list.item: One and a half lbs. of turtle steak
Pepper, lime juice, salt, bread or biscuit crumbs, nutmeg, tomato, skellion, two eggs

div.p: Cut the turtle into cutlets, rub well with onion, and sprinkle well with pepper, sauce and lime-juice. Get ready some bread or biscuit crumbs; add nutmeg and some onion or skellion and tomatoes finely minced: dip the cutlets into the eggs previously stirred in a plate, then into the seasoned crumbs; cover well, and fry, serving with cut lime and parsley.

div.head: 33. Turtle Balls

list.item: Turtle, one and a half lbs.
A small piece of salt beef
Tomato, skellion, lime-juice, salt, herbs, two eggs.

div.p: Mince the beef and turtle together very fine, add some chopped tomatoes, skellions, herbs, salt and a very little Jamaica fresh pepper: add a squeeze of lime juice, a little sauce a tablespoonful of sherry, a little spice and two well-beaten eggs. Make into balls and fry, sending them to table with a rich well seasoned brown gravy, to which add another teaspooful of sherry and lime.

div.head: 34. Turtle Steak

list.item: Lime juice, lard, pepper, onions, tomatoes, flour, butter.

div.p: Rub the steak well with lime juice. Have ready some boiling lard in a frying pan. Put in the meat whole. (Some people it cut in pieces, but it is really best done whole, or it is likely to get tough or dry.) Put with it some black pepper and sliced onions and tomatoes. Cover it over a little; when half done it will make its own gravy, but if not quite enough, add a tablespoonful of water, and if a thick gravy is liked a little flour and butter rubbed smoothly together with the water. The steak takes from twenty minutes to half na hour to cook.
Serve with the fat put on the top of the meat, squeeze some lime-juice over the whole and garnish with cut lime and slices of onion and tomatoes

div.head: 35. Turtle Stew

list.item: Two lbs. of turtle stew meat.
Cinnamon, nutmeg, pepper, ten cloves, one onion, a few tomatoes, parsley, thyme, sherry.
Two pounds of turtle stew meat.

div.p: Wash the meat well with salt and lime-juice and put it into a quart of cold water; then add a stick of cinnamon, a large onion, a few tomatoes, some parsley, thyme, herbs and pepper.

Stew gently for three hours, adding water now and then if it gets too low. About a quarter of an hour before serving, mix a good tablespoonful of flour smoothly with a little water, sufficiently liquid to pour into the pot to thicken the stew. Stir; at the last minute put in a desert spoonful of sauce and half a glass of sherry; mix well, and serve with a cut lime to squeeze over the meat.

div.head: 36. Black-Crabs, Boiled
div.p: These are liked either plain, boiled, or "baked in the back" as the expression is. Plain boiled, they come to table whole and they have really more flavour that way, but there are many small bones and there is much difficulty in eating them at table. The claws contain the principal meat; the back is to be opened and the gall removed; the black water inside possesses much flavour. When in full season the eggs are numerous and excellent: boiled in soup they are delicious.

div.head: 37. Black-Crabs, Baked
div.p: Carefully pick the meat from all the claws and smaller bones (it takes a long time and careful picking): then open the backs and extract the eggs, throwing away the galls and putting aside the black water to be added at the last. When all the picking is done, put to the meat two tablespoonfuls of butter, a teaspoonful of black pepper, a dessertspoonful of sauce of pepper-vinegar, a little cayenne and some nutmeg. Mix well, adding salt to taste, and fill as many of the backs as you can, leaving room for a dressings of bread-crumbs on which dabs of butter are placed to moisten. Before putting the meat into the backs, put one or two eggs in each shell and do not forget to mix in the black water, as that has the full black-crab flavour. The twelve crabs ought to make ten good crab-back fillings.

div.head: 38. Land Turtle or Terrapin
div.p: Cut off the head, and open the back. Remove the flesh from the inside and take away the bones, and also get what meat you can from the legs: Scald it with boiling water to remove the outer skin. Chop the meat into dice, adding a small piece of salt pork and salt beef, some tomatoes, skellion, herbs and black pepper with some cinnamon and nutmeg: add some sauce, butter, lime-juice, and a glass of sherry: mix all well and put into the turtle-back. Bread crumb the top, put dabs of butter here and there and bake in the shell. As there is not much meat in these turtle, it will take two turtle to fill one back.

div.head: III. SALT FISH.
div.p: It is suprising to most new-comers, to find that in Jamaica there is hardly a more popular dish among the natives and often among the upper classes than the despised salt fish, eaten at home not from choice, but as a sort of penitential dish. Here, it is the almost daily, and certainly the favourite food of the people generally; and cooked, as they cook it, it cannot fail to please the most fastidious.
The following are a few of the favourite methods of preparing it.

div.head: 39. Salt Fish and Akees

list.item: The fruit of twelve ackee pods.

div.p: Soak the salt-fish over night. Put it on in cold water to boil, otherwise it hardens: throw off the first water and put it on again to boil. Carefully pick the ackees free from all red inside, which is dangerous, and boil them for about twenty minutes; add them to the saltfish which is then cut in small pieces; add some lard, butter and pepper. Some prefer the saltfish and ackees mashed together and the melted lard and butter poured over the top.

div.head: 40. Salt Fish and Rice
div.p: This is a favourite native dish. The saltfish and rice, about a half a pound of salt fish to a pint of rice, are boiled together with the usual bit of salt pork and a little butter.

div.head: 41. Salt Fish Fritters No. 1
div.p: Some people add an egg or perhaps two to salt-fish and rice, and make fritters of it for breakfast.

div.head: 42. Salt Fish Fritters No. 2
div.p: Boiled salt-fish and ackees mixed together with pepper and seasoning make excellent fritters. No egg is required.

div.head: 43. Salt Fish Fritters No. 3

list.item: Tomatoes, skellions, butter, lard, parsley and two eggs.

div.p: Boil half a pound of the fish and mash it fine with some seasoning, a tablespoonful of butter, a teaspoonful of lard, a little chopped Jamaica fresh pepper (or some cayenne) and some minced tomatoes, skellions and herbs. Mix well with two well-beaten eggs and fry in fritters. These are very good for breakfast.

div.head: 44. Salt Herrings
div.p: Soak the herrings well. Then boil them changing the water once, or they may be too salt. Drain and serve with melted butter and parsley and garnished with slides of fresh pepper, fried onions and tomatoes.

div.head: 45. Salt Mackerel
div.p: Soak the fish some hours, then boil it, changing the water once to extract the salt. Put it on in cold water and let it come to a boil. Drain, and serve with butter, sauce, garnish with sliced lemons, tomatoes, and fresh peppers.

div.head: 46. Fried Salt Fish
div.p: Boil the fish first. Then cut it into pieces not too small, and fry with slices of onions and tomatoes, which serve on the top of the fish with slices of pepper and some parsley.

div.head: 47. Salt Mackerel Cutlets
div.p: Soak the mackerel for some hours; boil it, putting it on in cold water. Then cut the fish into slices, egg and bread crumb, and fry with lard.

div.head: 48. Salt Fish twice-laid

list.item: Four large potatoes or a good slice of any yam, except the yampee which is too sweet
One dessert spoonful of lard, skellion, parsley, pepper, tomatoes, herbs.

div.p: Boil the fish, chop and mix well with the potato or yam mashed, add the butter and lard, herbs, and other ingredients. Mix in two beaten eggs: butter a pie-dish, put in the mixture and bake a light brown.

div.head: 49. Curried Salt Fish
div.p: Saltfish stewed in the way mentioned in these receipts, and then curried, with the addition of a spoonful of mustard, is a very acceptable dish. Put a tablespoonful of curry powder and a squeeze of lime-juice to the mixture, and serve with rice balls.

div.head: 50. Salt Fish and Susumbers
div.p: Boil the salt-fish after soaking it a few hours; while boiling add some of the young susumber berries to the fish and boil till tender. They give it a bitterish taste highly appreciated by the natives, but not palatable to everybody, and one must be careful to choose the right kind of susumber as there are two sorts. This dish his served with melted butter and lard poured over it.

div.head: 51. Shredded Salt Fish
div.p: Soak some saltfish two hours, pull it to pieces in shreds, and fry with lard adding skellions, tomatoes and pepper.

div.head: 52. Salt Fish Patties

list.item: Half a lb. of saltfish stewed.
Skellions, tomatoes, pepper, onion, butter, sauce, parsley and herbs

div.p: Half a lb. of saltfish stewed with some skellions, tomatoes, pepper and a dessert spoonful of butter. Add a little sauce and nutmeg. Put in patty-pans lined with pastry. Cover and bake.

div.head: IV.— MEAT
div.p: Beef, mutton, pork and poultry are to be had in all the markets all over the island, and in the country parts distant from a market, there are always butchers who supply pork, or goal mutton at 6d. per lb. Now and then a cow is killed in the district, and then notice is given.

In this little work, I do not allude to any methods of dressing beef, sheep-mutton, pork or poultry; for my desire is merely to introduce to new-comers to Jamaica, our own native methods of cooking our own products, and by no means to attempt to cope with the many excellent works that at present exist on English or other cookery. It will be noticed therefore that nothing will be mentioned here except a few hints that may be of service to those who are strangers to our native dishes, provided as they must already be with cookery books which will guide them in the cooking of beef, mutton, pork or poultry.

There will be some surprise and perhaps discomfort on the part of the new-comer who finds that beef of all cuts, is sold at the same price, 6d per lb. no matter what one orders, unless one arranges with the butcher to give beef without bone at 7 1/2d per lb.; this of course would only be practicable with a round a steak, or a fillet. But the butchers charge 6d per lb. for bone as well as meat, and sometimes one is disappointed to find that when the "meat" is delivered, one half of it is "weigh-meat" or large pieces of bone. Sheep mutton is sold at 15 per lb. sometimes 10 1/2d. Pork from 6d to 7 1/2d oftener 7 1/2d; in the country parts it is always 6d the liver at 4 1/2d per lb., head 4 1/2d per lb. Poultry ought not to fetch more than 9d per lb. in the towns; 6d in the country parts, or at the highest 7 1/2d per lb. In and about Kingston the people hawk them about asking exhorbitant prices; it is always best to weigh them. Ducks vary from 10 1/2d to 15 per lb; turksy 15 per lb; pigeons is 6d a pair for the large 15 3d for the smaller. Wild birds vary in price, from the small ground dove at 3d each, to the larger birds going from 15 15 6d, 25 to 25 6d and 35 a pair. Guinea Birds 2s 6d each or 3s. Wild Guinea Birds 2s 6d each, or 5s to 6s per pair.
